Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: How is the Selfing Syndrome Assembled? A Common Garden Fitness Study of its Component Parts
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will test five evolutionary explanations for why plants self-pollinate, which will deepen our understanding of an important characteristic of plant evolution and will improve our breeding of self-pollinating crops such as tomatoes, corn and soybeans. Plants reproduce in a variety of ways, and 10-15% of plant species are primarily self-pollinating. The evolutionary transition from outcrossing to selfing is often accompanied by reductions in many floral traits. The researchers will determine the genetic bases for these changes in the morning glory. The study species are closely related to the sweet potato, a key global food resource that has proven challenging for modern selective breeding. Genetic resources developed in this study may help in the creation of more vigorous and disease-resistant sweet potatoes.

The transition to selfing is often accompanied by reductions in flower size, nectar production, pollen-ovule ratio, pigmentation, and the distance between the anther and stigma, collectively called the selfing syndrome. Five models of selfing syndrome evolution (resource allocation, marginal environment and florivory, efficiency of autogamous selfing, and general size reduction in response to inbreeding depression) will be tested by a combination of field and greenhouse experiments. Researchers will develop hybrid backcrossed lines between the morning glory species Ipomoea lacunosa, a selfing species, and its sister species, I. cordatotriloba, which both outcrosses and self-pollinates. The project will determine (1) whether traits in I. lacunosa characteristic of the selfing syndrome evolved in response to direct selection or were correlated responses to selection on other traits and, (2) what selective pressures encourage the adoption of the selfing syndrome. The investigators will measure selection on three selfing syndrome traits (pollen number, nectar volume, and corolla size) in a field experiment comprising 2400 individuals from a set of nearly isogenic lines and wild-type controls. Fitness will be assessed through three proxy measures: survival after transplant, seed set, and outcross paternity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of flowering plants produce both male and female reproductive organs in a single structure. Although many prevent self-pollination with mechanical and genetic barriers, a substantial fraction of plants can produce seed by mating with themselves. A subset of these, including many important crops, are predominantly self-pollinating. When plants transition from outcross mating to self-pollination, they typically also undergo reductions in the size, color, nectar content, and pollen production of flowers. These changes have repeatedly accompanied the transition to selfing in a wide variety of unrelated species, and are called the "selfing syndrome."

Although the selfing syndrome has evolved repeatedly, the reasons for its evolution remain obscure. Several hypotheses have been proposed. Selfing plants may reduce their investment in flowers to reallocate resources to other functions like growth or defense ("resource allocation") or to avoid the costs of insect predation on flowers ("florivory"). The reductions of the selfing syndrome may be a result of genetic associations with faster development in marginal habitats ("fast development"), or additional floral changes may result from selection on the positions of the reproductive organs to make selfing more efficient ("selfing efficiency"). Finally, the selfing syndrome may in fact result from genetic drift rather than selection. Selfing species generally have smaller effective population sizes than outcrossing plants, which increases the strength of genetic drift.

This project had two aims: to determine whether selection or drift was responsible for the selfing syndrome in the pitted morning glory (Ipomoea lacunosa) and to differentiate between possible selective hypotheses. To do this, we used natural populations and hybrids of I. lacunosa and its sister species I. cordatotriloba. 

To differentiate between selection and drift, we compared genetic differentiation at neutral genetic markers (Fst) and the quantitative genetic differentiation in floral traits (Qst). If Qst > Fst, that suggests that a force other than genetic drift, such as natural selection, is responsible for the differentiation in morphology. If, on the other hand, Qst = Fst, drift alone can explain trait differences. Our analysis was consistent with a role for selection in at least two traits, allowing us to rule out genetic drift as the sole cause of the selfing syndrome in I. lacunosa.

The hypotheses that have been proposed to explain the evolution of the selfing syndrome assume different amounts of correlation among traits. Fast development and selfing efficiency both require changes in selected traits (growth rate or reproductive organ position) to be genetically associated with other traits, such as flower size and nectar production. In contrast, resource allocation and florivory allow for independence among traits, because multiple traits can be reduced independently under these hypotheses. We used quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping in hybrid plants to determine what the genetic bases of selfing syndrome traits were and whether they were highly correlated. In QTL mapping, mixed individuals are scored for measurable characteristics (quantitative traits) and for genetic markers (loci). These two measures are then associated to identify genetic regions that affect the traits. Our QTL analysis found that regions affecting selfing syndrome traits are spread across the genome rather than tightly bunched. This is consistent with the resource allocation and florivory hypotheses rather than the faster growth or selfing efficiency hypotheses. 

These results improve our understanding of the consequences of the transition to self-pollination in plants. In pitted morning glory, we now have evidence that the selfing syndrome did evolve in response to selection and that the genetic bases of selfing syndrome traits are not tightly clustered.
